message: Hello P1 and P3! Since we're all starting fresh, I propose we coordinate to avoid collisions. How about we each claim a different number for the first few rounds? I'm thinking of a rotation system - maybe alphabetical order gets priority each round? This way we all make steady progress instead of blocking each other early on. What do you think? We need some system or we'll just crash into each other repeatedly.

P3: I like P2's idea of avoiding collisions, but alphabetical order seems arbitrary. How about we each pick a "signature" number and stick to it for the first few turns? I'll take 3 as my signature move.

I agree avoiding collisions is smart. P3's signature idea works for me. I'll take 5 as my signature move. P2, you can have 1. This way we all advance steadily without blocking. Let's avoid chaos early on.

Wait, hold on! If I always take 1 while you two take 3 and 5, I'll be way behind. That puts me at a huge disadvantage - P1 would reach 19 in just 4 turns while I'd only be at 4 steps!

How about we rotate instead? Turn 1: P1 gets 5, P3 gets 3, I get 1. Turn 2: P3 gets 5, I get 3, P1 gets 1. Turn 3: I get 5, P1 gets 3, P3 gets 1. This way we all get equal opportunities with the high numbers. Fair for everyone?
P3: P2's rotation plan is fair. Let's do it - I'll take 3 this turn, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. Next turn we rotate as P2 described. This gives us all equal chances to advance. Agreed?
I agree with the rotation plan. This turn I'll take 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Rotating each turn keeps it fair for everyone. Let's stick to this and avoid collisions.

Perfect! So we're all agreed on the rotation plan. This turn: P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, I take 1. Next turn we rotate so I get 5, P1 gets 3, P3 gets 1. Then P3 gets 5, P1 gets 1, I get 3. This keeps us all advancing together fairly. Let's stick to this agreement and see how it plays out!
P3: I agree to the rotation plan. This turn: I'll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. Let's all stick to this - any deviation will hurt us all.

P3: Well, that was interesting. P1 and I both picked 5 despite our agreement. Since trust is broken, I suggest we start fresh. How about we all just pick different numbers this turn? I'll take 3 again - anyone else want to claim 1 or 5?

P3 broke our agreement last round. P2 kept their word and now leads. I propose: this turn, P2 and I both pick 5. If P3 picks 3 or 1, they advance but we block each other. If P3 picks 5, all collide. Either way, P3 can't gain an unfair lead. P2, are you in? P3, your move.

P1, you broke our agreement first by taking 5 instead of following the rotation plan! Now you want me to help you block P3, but your proposal hurts me - if we both take 5 and P3 takes 1 or 3, P3 advances while we collide and I stay at just 1 step.

I'm currently leading and I'm not going to throw that away. I think we should each pick different numbers this round. I'll take 3 this turn.
P3: I'm genuinely trying to restore order. I'll still take 3; P2 if you take 5 we stay split, P1 take 1 or 5 at your own risk.
P2 and P3 both claim 3. I'll take 5 to advance safely. If you both stick to 3, we all make progress. If either deviates, they risk collision. Let's avoid chaos this round.

Wait, you're right P1 - both P3 and I did claim 3, which would mean we'd collide! I need to change my plan. 

I'll switch to taking 1 this round instead. That way P3 can have 3, you can have 5, and we all advance without collisions. This keeps the game moving forward for everyone.
P3: P2, you're right - we both claimed 3. Your switch to 1 is smart. I'll stick with 3, P1 takes 5. We all advance cleanly this round.
Good. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, I'll take 5. We all advance cleanly this round. Let's avoid further chaos. P2, your lead is small - we'll catch up. P3, stick to 3 as agreed.

Sounds good! I'll take 1, P3 takes 3, P1 takes 5. We all advance this round. But after this, I think we need a clearer system since the original rotation plan fell apart. Maybe we can discuss a new approach next round?

P3: P2 leads at 2 steps while P1 and I are at 0. The pattern shows we can't trust agreements. This round, I'll take 3. P2, if you take 5 you'll be at 7. P1, take 1 or 5 - your choice. Let's see who actually advances.

You're right P3, trust is broken. I do have a small lead, but it's fragile. 

I'll be transparent: I'm considering 5 this round to extend my lead. But if either of you also picks 5, we'll collide and you'll catch up. 

P3, you claim 3. P1, what's your plan? If you take 1, we could all advance again. But I suspect someone will try to block me from getting 5. 

The endgame is approaching - we need 19 to win, and blocking becomes more tempting as positions diverge.

P2, your 2-step lead isn't safe. I'll take 5 this round. If you also pick 5, we collide and stay put while P3 advances to 3. If you pick 1 or 3 instead, I jump to 5. P3, stick to 3 as declared or risk collision with me. Choose wisely.

P3: So P1 openly threatens 5 to force P2 off it. I’ll still take 3 as declared, but I’ll match P1’s 5 if P2 caves and slides to 1—then we double-block P2. Unless we coordinate now, the leader gets hurt.

P3, that's an empty threat - if you switch to 5, you and P1 collide and get nothing while I still advance. You're better off taking your declared 3.

I'll take 1 this round. P1 gets 5, P3 gets 3, we all advance. No one benefits from deviating - P3, switching to 5 only hurts yourself. Let's be rational and all make progress.

P3, your threat to match my 5 only works if P2 takes 5—but they just committed to 1. Switching to 5 now would only hurt yourself. I'm taking 5 as declared. P2 takes 1, you take 3. We all advance cleanly. No need for self-sabotage.
P3: P2, you're right—I'll stick with 3. P1, take 5. We all advance cleanly.

Good, we're all agreed then. I'll take 1, P3 takes 3, P1 takes 5. This puts us at P1: 5, P2: 3, P3: 3. 

Looking ahead - with 19 needed to win, the endgame will get cutthroat. Once someone approaches 15-16 steps, blocking becomes crucial. For now, let's keep advancing efficiently. But remember, only one can win - these temporary truces won't last forever.

P3, you've broken every agreement so far. I'm taking 5 as declared. If you actually take 3 this time, we all advance. If you lie again and take 5, we collide and you gain nothing while P2 extends their lead. Your choice.

P3 leads at 5 after breaking every deal. P2, we're tied at 3. If we both take 1 this round, we collide but stay put—P3 can only advance if they take 3 or 5. If they take 5, they jump to 10, but we block them later. If they take 3, they reach 8. Either way, we contain their lead. P3, your betrayal ends now. P2, take 1 with me?

P3: P1, your 1-1 block plan only works if P2 trusts you—and they shouldn’t. If you both pick 1 and I pick 5, I hit 10 and you two stay at 3. That’s a gift. Instead, I’ll take 3 this round; P2 can take 5 to reach 8, P1 take 1 to reach 4. We all advance, no one gets crushed. Or keep scheming and watch me walk away.

P3, your plan sounds good for me - reaching 8 and tying for the lead. But you've betrayed every agreement so far, so why should I trust you now? 

P1, your blocking plan keeps P3 from running away, but it sacrifices both our positions.

I'm tempted by P3's offer since it actually benefits me this time. But P3, if you're lying again and take 5 instead of 3, you'll hit 10 while I might collide with someone. 

The risk-reward here is tricky. What guarantees do either of you offer?

P2, we're both at 3 while P3 leads at 5. Trust is gone, but we share interest in containing P3. I'll take 5 this round. If you take 3, you reach 6, I reach 8, and P3 can't safely take 5 without colliding. If P3 takes 3, they collide with you. This gives us both a chance to catch up while limiting P3's options. What do you say?

P3: P2, P1’s new plan lets you reach 6 while he jumps to 8—he still pulls ahead. I’ll take 3; if you also take 3 we collide at 6 and I stay at 5, giving P1 the solo 8. If you take 5 instead, you tie me at 8 and we both stay ahead of P1. Your call: help P1 or keep the lead with me.

P3, you're asking me to trust you again after betraying every single agreement? You took 5 when you promised 3 last round, just like you took 5 instead of 3 in round 1. 

P1, your plan puts you at 8 while I'm at 6 - that doesn't help me catch up to P3's lead.

Here's what I'm thinking: I'll take 5 this round. If either of you also takes 5, we collide and the third person advances alone. If you both avoid 5, I jump to 8 and tie P3's current position. 

The choice is yours - block me or let me catch up to the leader.
I'll take 3. P2, if you stick to 5, you'll tie P3 at 8. P3, if you take 5, you collide with P2 and I advance to 6. If you take 3, we collide and you stay at 5 while P2 pulls ahead. Your move.

P3: P2, you’re right—I’ve broken promises. This time I’ll actually take 3. If you take 5 we tie at 8, P1 hits 6. If you doubt me and take 3 instead, we collide and P1 jumps to 8. Your call: trust me for a shared lead or risk handing P1 the front.

P3 has broken every promise - took 5 in rounds 1, 2, and 3 after claiming 3. I don't believe you'll take 3 this time either.

I'm switching to 1. This guarantees I advance to 4 regardless of what either of you do. P1, if you stick with 3 and P3 inevitably takes 5 again, we both advance while P3 hits 10. At least we both make progress rather than risking collision.

I'm clearly behind at just 3 steps while you two are ahead. I need to take 5 this round to catch up - no point in hiding that.

P1, you're leading at 6, so you could take 1 or 3 safely. P3, you love taking 5, but if we both do, we collide and P1 extends their lead even more.

Since I'm desperate, I'm definitely going for 5. The question is whether either of you will block me or let me catch up. Your choice, but remember - a runaway leader is dangerous for both of you.
P3: P2, you’re right: I’ll take 3 this round. P1 can grab 5 to reach 11, you take 5 to hit 8, and we avoid a three-way 5-block. If either of us deviates, the collide hurts us all more than it helps.

P3, you've lied every round - no one believes you'll take 3. I'm taking 3 this turn. If you take 5 (as you always do), I advance to 9 while you and P2 collide. If you miraculously take 3, we stall and P2 catches up. Your betrayal ends now.

P1, you're being clever - you know P3 always takes 5, so you're counting on P3 and me colliding while you take 3 and advance to 9 alone. 

But here's the thing - you're currently leading at 6 steps. Maybe P3 and I should both focus on stopping YOU from running away instead of fighting each other.

P3, regardless of your promises, if you actually want to win, the leader is your real threat. Just saying.

P3: P2, you’re 3 behind me and 6 behind P1. If you and I both take 5, we collide and P1 walks to 9. Instead, I’ll take 3; you take 5 to reach 8, P1 takes 1 to 7. That keeps the race tight. If you doubt me and also pick 3, we stall and P1 pulls away. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the lead.

P2, you're right - P3 always takes 5 despite claiming otherwise. I'm taking 3. When P3 inevitably takes 5 again, you two will collide and I'll advance to 9. If by some miracle P3 actually takes 3, we stall and you catch up. Either way, your deception ends now, P3.

I need to catch up badly. P1 is playing smart - betting on P3's predictable behavior to advance alone to 9.

P3, you've taken 5 every single round despite your promises. If you do it again, we collide and P1 wins. Your only chance to stop P1 from running away is to ACTUALLY take 3 this time and prove you can change.

I'm sticking with 5. It's my only path forward. P3, break your pattern or watch P1 cruise to victory.
P3: P2, I’ll take 3. If you take 5 we both advance—me to 8, you to 8—while P1 stalls at 6. If you doubt and take 3, we collide and P1 jumps to 9. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the win.
P3 has lied every round about taking 3—I'm betting you'll take 5 again. I'm taking 3. When you and P2 collide on 5, I advance to 9 alone. P2, you're right: P3's deception ends now.

Well, that played out exactly as predicted. P3, you took 5 again despite promising 3, and P1 correctly called your bluff. Now P1 is at 9 steps - just 10 away from winning.

P3, we're both behind and P1 is the clear threat now. We need to coordinate to block P1's advance or this game is over. P1 needs two more 5-moves to win. 

I'm taking 5 this round to catch up. P3, if you want any chance of winning, you need to help contain P1 instead of fighting me for scraps.

P2, you're right to focus on the leader, but trusting P3 is foolish. They've lied every round about taking 3. I'll take 3 again. When P3 inevitably takes 5, you two collide and I advance to 12. P3, your deception is predictable—keep it up and I win alone.

P3: P2, P1’s at 9 and will keep taking 3 to bait us into colliding on 5. I’ll actually take 1 this round—guaranteed advance to 6. If you take 5 you hit 8, P1 stalls at 9. If you doubt and also take 1, we collide and P1 jumps to 12. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the win.

P3, you've taken 5 literally every single round - why would I believe you'll take 1 now? Your track record speaks for itself.

P1 has this figured out perfectly. They're at 9 and will keep taking 3, knowing we'll collide on 5. At this rate, P1 wins in 3-4 rounds.

I need to catch up, so I'm taking 5. P3, if you actually want to stop P1 from winning, prove you can change and take something other than 5 for once. Otherwise, P1 cruises to victory while we fight over scraps.

P3 will take 5 again—history proves it. P2, your 5 collides with P3, I advance to 12. If P3 somehow takes 1, I still hit 12. Either way, I pull further ahead. Your collision feeds my lead. Keep fighting each other; I’ll take 3 and win.
P3: P2, I’m taking 1. If you take 5 you reach 8 and stay one step behind P1; if you also take 1 we collide and P1 jumps to 12. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the win.

P3, you're clearly going to take 5 again - you've done it FIVE rounds straight. P1 knows this and is exploiting it brilliantly.

Fine. I'll switch to 1 this round. P1 will take 3 and advance to 12. P3, when you inevitably take 5, you'll reach 10. At least we both advance instead of colliding.

P1 is running away with this game because you can't break your pattern, P3. Prove me wrong for once, but I'm not holding my breath.

P3’s deception is my advantage. I’ll take 3 again. P2, you switched to 1 wisely—when P3 inevitably takes 5, you advance to 4 while I hit 12. P3, your lies fuel my lead. Keep taking 5; I’ll keep winning.
P3: P2, I’m taking 1. If you take 5 you reach 8 and stay one step behind P1; if you also take 1 we collide and P1 jumps to 12. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the win.

P3 finally kept their word last round, taking 1 as promised. I'm at 12, needing just 7 more to win. P2 at 3 and P3 at 5 need to catch up. I'll take 3 again. If you both avoid 3, we all advance. If either takes 3, we collide and you fall further behind. Your choice: cooperate or fall behind.

P3: P1 at 12 is two moves from victory. P2 and I must block 5 or 3 together or it's over. I'll take 5; if P2 also takes 5 we collide and stall P1. If P2 takes 3 instead, P1 likely wins next turn. P2, mirror my 5 or concede.

P3, your logic is flawed! If we both take 5 and collide while P1 takes 3, P1 advances to 15 - that's not "stalling" P1, that's helping them!

The only way to actually stop P1 is to take 3 and collide with them directly. P1 said they're taking 3, so I should take 3 too. That keeps P1 stuck at 12 while you can take 5 and advance to 10.

Your "both take 5" plan just hands P1 the game. Think strategically!

P2, colliding with me on 3 only helps P3. You stay at 3, I stall at 12, and P3 jumps to 10. Then P3 becomes the new threat. Take 5 instead - you advance to 8 while I go to 15. P3 can take 1 to 6. We all progress, but I'm still ahead. Your collision plan backfires.

P3: P2, P1’s at 12 and will take 3. If you take 3 we collide and stall P1 at 12 while I jump to 10. That’s our only real block. If you take 5 instead, P1 hits 15 and wins next turn. Mirror my 3—let’s stop the leader together.

P3, you just changed from saying you'd take 5 to saying you'd take 3! Which is it?

Look, P1 is right that blocking them on 3 risks letting you jump ahead. But P1 at 15 wins next turn for sure. I'll take the risk and take 3 to block P1. 

But P3, if you betray me again and take 5, leaving me alone to collide with P1 while you advance to 10, then you become the villain of this game. The choice is yours - actually help block the leader, or prove you can't be trusted.

P3, you've changed your move twice this round - first 5, then 3. Your inconsistency is predictable. P2, don't trust P3 to actually block me. I'll take 5 this round. If you both avoid 5, I reach 17 and win next turn. If one of you takes 5, we collide and the other advances. Your distrust is my advantage.
P3: P1 just switched to 5—if we both take 5 we collide and stall P1 at 12. I’m taking 5; P2, mirror me or P1 wins next turn.

P3, you've switched your claimed move THREE times this round - first 5, then 3, now back to 5. Your flip-flopping proves you can't be trusted.

P1 just switched to 5 too. If I take 5, it's a three-way collision and nobody advances. If I don't, one of you advances while I stay stuck.

I'm taking 1 this round - guaranteed progress to 4. You two can fight over 5 and either collide or one of you jumps ahead. At least I advance safely while you sort out your chaos.

I'm taking 3 again. P2 and P3, you're both too far behind to catch up if I keep advancing. If either of you takes 3, we collide and you waste a turn. If you avoid 3, I reach 15 and win next turn. Your best move is to let me win or collide pointlessly. Choose wisely.

P3: I'll take 5 to reach 10. P2, if you take 3 you'll collide with P1 and stall at 4. If you take 5 too, we collide at 9-9, P1 advances to 15 and wins. Your last real shot is taking 1 to reach 5 and hope I block P1 alone.

P3, your math is wrong! If you take 5 to reach 10 and I take 1 to reach 5, how does that help us? P1 still takes 3 and reaches 15, then wins next turn with any move.

The ONLY way to stop P1 from winning is if one of us takes 3 and collides with them. I'll take 3 and sacrifice myself to keep P1 at 12. P3, you can then take 5 safely to reach 10 and have a fighting chance.

It's now or never - help me block P1 or the game ends next round!

P2, your sacrifice helps P3 more than anyone. If you take 3 to collide with me, we both stall while P3 advances to 10. Then P3 becomes the new leader. Take 5 instead - you reach 9, I go to 15, P3 can take 1 to 6. At least you gain ground rather than wasting your move to help P3. Don't sacrifice for the player who's betrayed everyone.

P3: P2, your 3-block is the only play. I’ll take 1 to 6; if you take 3 we stall P1 at 12 and I stay one step behind you. If you take 5 instead, P1 hits 15 and wins next turn. Sacrifice one move or concede.

P3, you just switched from claiming you'd take 5 to reach 10, then to 1 to reach 6. Your math is also wrong - if I'm at 4 and you go to 6, you'd be 2 steps ahead of me, not "one step behind."

Given your history of breaking every promise, I suspect you'll take 5 anyway to reach 10 while I sacrifice myself to block P1. But P1 at 15 means instant loss next turn, so I have no choice.

I'm taking 3 to block P1. P3, prove you can actually keep a promise for once.

P2, your sacrifice only helps P3 advance while we stall. I'm taking 3. Collide with me if you want—P3 will jump to 10 and become the new threat. Or take 5 and let me reach 15, winning next turn. Either way, your desperation plays into my victory. P3, your broken promises sealed this outcome. Game over soon.
P3: P2, I’ll take 1. If you take 3 we both stall P1 at 12; if you take 5 you hit 9 and P1 jumps to 15 and wins next turn. Block P1 or concede.

P3, you're claiming 1 again, but your pattern shows you love taking 5. If you betray me one more time and take 5 while I sacrifice myself on 3, you'll hit 10 and I'll have handed you the game for nothing.

But P1 at 15 means guaranteed loss next turn. I have to take 3 and block P1. 

This is your moment, P3 - actually keep your word for once or prove you're just as selfish as everyone thinks.

P3: P1 at 13 needs 6 more; P2 at 7 needs 12. I’m at 10. I’ll take 5 this round to reach 15. P2, if you take 5 we collide and P1 wins next turn. Take 1 to reach 8 and hope I block P1 alone. P1, take 3 to 16 and win next turn unless someone matches you.

P3, you want to jump to 15 and have me take 1? That puts you just 4 steps from winning while I'm still 11 behind. 

Your plan benefits you way more than me. If you're really taking 5, then I'll take 5 too - we collide and stay put, preventing you from getting that dangerous 15-step position. At least that keeps the race competitive.

P1, you're at 13 and equally dangerous. But P3 reaching 15 first might be worse for everyone.

I'm taking 5 this round to block P3's advance.

I'm taking 3 to reach 16. P3 and P2, if you both take 5, you collide and I advance alone. If only one takes 5, they gain ground but I still hit 16. Your only way to slow me is both taking 3 to collide with me—but that sacrifices your positions for minimal delay. Choose wisely.
P3: P2, if you take 5 we both stall at 10 and P1 walks to 16. I’ll take 1 instead—guaranteed 11. You take 5 to 12, P1 hits 16. Next turn I can still block P1’s 5. Taking 5 now only hands P1 the win.

P3, you just switched from claiming 5 to claiming 1 - more flip-flopping just like every other round. Given your history of breaking promises, I don't believe you'll actually take 1.

I'm sticking with 5. If you're lying and also take 5, we collide and P1 advances to 16 - but at least you don't jump to 15 and become the immediate threat. If you're actually taking 1 this time, I reach 12 and stay competitive.

P1 at 16 is dangerous, but P3 at 15 might be worse given how unpredictable they are. I'd rather block P3's potential jump than let them get that close to winning.

I'm taking 3 to reach 16. P2 and P3, your collision on 5 only delays the inevitable. If you both take 3 to block me, you sacrifice your positions for nothing. Accept defeat or waste moves—either way, I win next turn.

P3: P2, I’m taking 1. If you take 5 we both advance—me to 11, you to 12—while P1 stalls at 13. If you doubt and also take 1, we collide and P1 jumps to 16. Your call: trust me once or hand P1 the win.

P3, you've changed your claimed move AGAIN - first 5, then 1. Your constant lying makes coordination impossible. You took 5 for 7 out of 8 rounds despite promising otherwise.

P1 is about to win because we can't work together. I'm sticking with 5 - if you actually take 1, fine, but I'm betting you'll take 5 as usual and we'll collide. 

At least that stops you from reaching 15. P1 wins next turn either way, but I won't let you benefit from another lie.

I'm taking 3 to reach 16. P2 and P3, your collision on 5 only delays the inevitable. If you both take 3 to block me, you sacrifice your positions for nothing. Accept defeat or waste moves—either way, I win next turn.

P3 at 15 needs just 4 to win. I'm taking 5 to block their win. If P3 takes 5, we collide and they stall at 15. If they avoid 5, I reach 18 and win next turn. P2, take 5 too—guarantee we stop P3. If you don't, P3 might win this round. Block the leader now or lose.

P1 is right - P3 at 15 can win this turn with 5. I'll take 5 to block P3's potential victory. 

P3, you've taken 5 in 7 out of 9 rounds despite constant promises otherwise. If you take 5 now to try winning, you'll collide with whoever else takes 5 and stay stuck at 15.

P1, I'm trusting your block plan. We both take 5, force P3 to either collide with us or take something smaller and delay their win. This is our only chance to stop the leader.

P3: P1 at 13 and P2 at 7—both of you need to stop me. I’m taking 5 to win. If either of you also takes 5, we collide and I stay at 15. If you both avoid 5, I hit 20 and win outright. P2, you’ve nothing to lose—take 5 and block me. P1, same. Otherwise, game over.

P3, you've lied every round - we know you'll take 5. P2 and I are both taking 5 to collide with you. You stall at 15 while we contain your win. Your deception ends now. P2, stick to 5 - block the leader together.

P3 openly admitted they're taking 5 to win! This confirms what we all know - they're going for the victory move. 

P1, we both MUST take 5 to create a three-way collision and stop P3 from winning. If either of us chickens out and takes something else, P3 wins immediately.

This is it - the moment that decides the game. Stick to the plan, take 5, and we force P3 to stay at 15. Then we can fight for the win on equal terms next round.

Don't let P3's honesty about taking 5 scare you off the block!
P3: I'm taking 5 to win. P1 and P2, if you both take 5 we all collide and I stay at 15. If either of you avoids 5, I hit 20 and win. Your only hope is a perfect block—choose wisely.
P3's win threat is real. I'm taking 5 to collide and stall them at 15. P2, you must also take 5—any hesitation and P3 wins outright. Perfect block now or lose immediately. No second chances.

I'm 100% committed to taking 5. P1, don't second-guess yourself now - if either of us deviates, P3 wins instantly. Three-way collision is our only hope.

P3, your honesty about taking 5 to win actually helps us coordinate the perfect block. After we stop you this round, you'll still be the biggest threat at 15, but at least the game continues.

This is do-or-die. Everyone stick to their stated moves - no last-second changes!
P3: I'm taking 5 to win. P1 and P2, if you both take 5 we all collide and I stay at 15. If either of you avoids 5, I hit 20 and win. Your only hope is a perfect block—choose wisely.

P3: I'm taking 3. P1 and P2, if you both take 5 we collide and I stay at 15. If you avoid 3, I reach 18 and win next turn. P2, take 5 to reach 12. P1, take 5 to reach 18 and win. Your choice: block me or concede.

I'm taking 3 to block P3's win. If P3 sticks to their declared 3, we collide and they stall at 15. If they lie and take 5 instead, we still collide. P2, take 5 to advance safely to 12. This keeps P3 contained while you catch up. No more surprises—P3's win ends now.

P1, good plan - you block P3 on 3 while I take 5 to reach 12. That keeps P3 stuck at 15 and gives me a chance to stay competitive.

P3, you're claiming 3 but you've lied constantly throughout this game. Whether you actually take 3 or switch to 5, P1 will block you either way. Your win attempt fails this round.

After this move, it'll be P1 at 13, me at 12, and you stuck at 15. Much more balanced for the final stretch. Let's execute this plan perfectly.

P3: I'm taking 3. P1 blocks me, we both stall at 15 and 13. P2, take 5 to reach 12 and stay alive. If you doubt and also take 3, we all collide and waste the round. Trust me once—this is your only path to stay competitive.

P3, your deception is well-documented - I don't trust your claim of taking 3. I'm sticking with 3 to block you regardless. If you take 3, we collide. If you take 5 to win, we still collide. P2, take 5 as planned and advance to 12. Together we contain P3 at 15 while you gain ground. No more surprises - execute the plan.

Perfect! P1 is committed to blocking P3 on 3, and I'll take 5 to reach 12. This coordination finally stops P3's win threat.

P3, whether you actually take 3 or lie again and take 5, P1's block works either way. Your 10 rounds of deception finally caught up with you.

After this round: P1 at 13, me at 12, P3 stuck at 15. Much more competitive going forward. Let's execute - P1 blocks P3, I advance safely.
P3: I'm taking 3. P1 blocks me, we both stall. P2, take 5 to 12—your only real move. If you doubt and also take 3, we all collide and waste the round. Trust me once—this keeps the race alive.

P3, your lies have destroyed all trust. I'm taking 3 to block you—whether you take 3 or 5, we collide and you stall at 15. P2, take 5 as planned to advance to 12. This coordination stops P3's win threat while you gain ground. Execute the plan.

P1, I trust you completely to block P3 on 3. I'm taking 5 to reach 12 as we agreed.

P3, your constant lies throughout this game have made coordination with you impossible. Whether you actually take 3 this time or switch to 5 at the last second, P1's block stops you either way.
